description: Borrowed from Latin recēns (genitive recentis). As classifier for a geological epoch coinciding with human presence (“Recent era”) introduced by  Charles Lyell in 1833.

adjectives.description: recent (comparative more recent, superlative most recent)

entries.meaning: Having happened a short while ago.
Having done something a short while ago that distinguishes them as what they are called.
examples: The cause has several hundred recent donors.
I met three recent graduates at the conference.

entries.meaning: (sciences) Particularly in geology, palaeontology, and astronomy: having occurred a relatively short time ago, but still potentially thousands or even millions of years ago.
examples: Finding it now means it was produced in more recent times, in astronomical terms.

entries.meaning: (obsolete, geology, astronomy, capitalized) Of the Holocene, particularly pre-21st century.
(obsolete, geology, capitalized) An earlier term for the Holocene.
